newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Ahold upbeat about Spanish joint venture.
newsitem.headline: Ahold upbeat about Spanish joint venture.

text.p: Dutch supermarket giant Ahold NV made a long-awaited breakthrough into the Spanish food retail market on Tuesday, forging a 50/50 joint venture with Caprabo, set to contribute to group profits in the medium term.
The first move by the joint venture, dubbed Store 2000, was the takeover of 10 supermarkets in Madrid in a deal worth "several millions of guilders", Ahold said.
"Our two companies plan to jointly develop a national supermarket-hypermarket business in Spain, excluding Catalonia and the Baleares, where Caprabo has its own supermarket operations," Ahold said.
Spokesman Hans Gobes was upbeat about the venture, which he called a mid to longer term investment.
"We believe we can generate -- in the next five to 10 years -- the same growth as we see in Portugal," he told Reuters.
"But it's a much bigger market (in Spain) so the scale is considerable."
In the second quarter of 1995, sales in local currency at Ahold's Pingo Doce and Feira Nova stores in Portugal rose 14.0 percent.
Barcelona-based Caprabo was founded in May 1959 and operates 90 supermarkets and hypermarkets with total sales of 85 billion pesetas and a staff of 3,500.
Gobes said the joint venture would not affect the group's earnings per share target of 15 percent growth per annum.

He added the group would still look out for acquisition opportunities in southern Europe. "We have always looked in the southern part of Europe -- in Spain and Italy -- and we will continue to do that now with our start in Spain," he said.
Gobes said further acquisitions by the joint venture in Spain would occur in time.
"We believe that we can grow in a steady way and that there are quite a number of opportunities in Spain so we will deliver when we have another one," Gobes said.

He said Ahold aimed to be a dominant player in the Spanish food retail market. "It's too early to predict market share, but we've always believed that we have to be market leader or number two, so we want to be dominant players (in Spain)," he said.
"We have been looking for quite a number of years for a good partner (in Spain) and now we believe we've found an excellent one," Gobes added.
"They have excellent management and know-how about food and non-food retailing. They know the territory very well...so we really have the right team to make excellent progress."
By 1350 GMT, Ahold shares were up 0.70 guilders at 97.60, off an earlier new year record high of 97.80 guilders.
